Description: Emerged primarily on the United States east coast in African American communities in the late 1970s; emphasizes rhythmic beat patterns and a type of spoken vocal delivery known as rapping.

Abstract Hip Hop.Description: Uses much more abstract lyricism than what is considered conventional within the genre, typically through use of metaphors, symbolism, and cryptic meanings.

Afroswing.Description:
Emerged in the United Kingdom during the mid-2010s, incorporating influences from
      Dancehall, Afrobeats, Contemporary R&B, and a variety of West African Music.

Afro Trap.Description: Centered mostly in France, features production influenced by modern styles developed in West and Central Africa with Trap-styled vocal flows.

Arabesque Rap.Description: Emerged from Turkey in the late 2000s, based almost exclusively around Arabesk samples and featuring aggressive rap vocals.

Bongo Flava.Description: Tanzanian genre originating in the mid-1990s in the Dar es Salaam area, combining the influence of Rhythm & Blues, Afrobeat, and Dancehall with native Tanzanian styles like Taarab and Muziki wa dansi.

Boom Bap.Description: Production style identified by an acoustic-sounding drum pattern of a kick drum on the downbeat followed by a cracking snare on the upbeat.

Bounce.Description: Developed in New Orleans in the early 1990s, initially defined by a slow to midtempo beat with a double-time hi-hat on top.

Chipmunk Soul.Description: Sped-up vocal samples and slick soulful production.

Chopped and Screwed.Description: Remixing technique pioneered by the late Houston producer DJ Screw in the 1990s, where tracks are slowed down and remixed with a skipping effect.

Christian Hip Hop.Description: Employs lyrics with a pro-Christianity message to profess the performer's faith, and often to attract new attention from potential converts.

Cloud Rap.Description: Emerged in the early 2010s, known for its relaxed, dream-like, and reverb-heavy production style, taking influence from Chillwave, and producers' obscure sample choices.

Comedy Rap.Description: Primarily intended to be humorous, through the use of comedic lyrics, production, delivery, or other musical aspects.

Conscious Hip Hop.Description: Artists whose lyrics deal with social issues.

Country Rap.Description: Combines the flow, production-emphasis, and demeanor of Hip Hop with the lyrical content and general approach of Country.

Crunk.Description: Originating from the southern United States and reliant on drum machines and synthesizer stabs to create an energetic, often dance-oriented sound.

Drill.Description: Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s, broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms, coupled with street-conscious and often violent rapping.

Emo Rap.Description: Moody, melancholic production combining atmospheric Cloud Rap, and Trap's typical drum programming, with sampling from Alternative Rock, Midwest Emo, Emo-Pop, and Pop Punk.

Experimental Hip Hop.Description: Incorporates experimental and eccentric elements considered unconventional or unorthodox compared to more traditional hip hop.

Industrial Hip Hop.Description: Incorporates harsh elements inspired by Industrial music such as blaring, noisy synths, distorted and metallic percussion, as well as more aggressive and off-kilter rapping styles.

French Hip Hop.Description: Hip Hop originating from France, typically performed in the French language.

Genge.Description: Combines elements of Dancehall with various traditions of Kenya.

G-Funk.Description: Relaxed and organic sound featuring live instrumentation, use of P-Funk samples, and high-pitched synth lines.

Hardcore Hip Hop.Description: Characterized by confrontation and aggression, whether in the lyricism, vocal delivery, hard beats, heavy production, or any combination thereof.

Britcore.Description: British subgenre from the late 1980s and early 1990s featuring fast breakbeats and rapping.

Gangsta Rap.Description: Lyrics from a gangster's perspective, typically within the Hardcore Hip Hop sound.

Horrorcore.Description: Lyrical content and imagery focus on the macabre and morbid, including such topics as Satanism and suicide, with production generally of a darker nature than is typically found in other Hip Hop.

Memphis Rap.Description: Characterized by minimalistic half-time drum machine programming with droning bass, often paired with aggressive rapping and a double time flow.

Mid-School Hip Hop.Description: Based around heavy drum machine production sound.

Trap Metal.Description: Features loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.

Jersey Drill.Description: Mixes Drill and Jersey Club production, characterized by an energetic sound and distinct syncopated rhythms.

Hipco.Description: Developed in Liberia, often featuring conscious and political lyrics and influences from local dance styles.

Hiplife.Description: Fusion of Ghanaian Highlife with Hip Hop.

Hyphy.Description: Party-focused style with upbeat tempos, heavy bass and prominent synths, all underpinned by a distinctive West Coast-style rhythm, claps on beats 2 and 4, and a strong kick drum on beats 1, 2, and either 3 or 4.

Instrumental Hip Hop.Description: Can take the form of instrumental versions of songs that normally feature rapping, or hip hop originally released and always intended to be instrumental.

Japanese Hip Hop.Description: Hip Hop which is created by artists who are either based in or from Japan.

Jazz Rap.Description: Incorporates elements of Jazz through the use of samples or live instrumentation.

Jerk.Description: Sparse, snare-heavy drum patterns loosely inspired by Jerk Rap, which take major elements from other prominent 2010s and 2020s underground hip hop genres like Plugg.

Jersey Club Rap.Description: Incorporates Jersey Club's distinct kick-heavy rhythms, which are modified to better suit rapping, featuring less sampling and more atmospheric production than earlier jersey club.

Jersey Drill.Description: Mixes Drill and Jersey Club production, characterized by an energetic sound and distinct syncopated rhythms.

Jigg.Description: Club-oriented genre characterized by heavy 808-driven beats, imposing synthesized brasses and an uptempo rhythm.

Jook.Description: Fast-paced; draws influence from Bounce, Miami Bass, Jersey Club and Dancehall.

Latin Rap.Description: Primarily done in Spanish; incorporates Hispanic American Music elements into its sound.

Lo-Fi Hip Hop.Description: Relaxed, laid-back form of Hip Hop, typically instrumental and influenced by Jazz Rap and Downtempo.

Lowend.Description: Rhythms driven by steady eighth-note digital handclaps, rattling bass, fast tempos, upbeat sound, and laid-back flows.

Miami Bass.Description: Sustained Roland TR-808 kick drums and faster tempos, along with a distinct Electro influence.

Mobb Music.Description: San Francisco Bay Area production style building on slowed down Funk (often utilizing live elements).

Nerdcore Hip Hop.Description: Themes touch on such nerd mainstays as science, computers, and science fiction.

Nervous Music.Description: Dark, sinister and menacing sound, heavy sub-basses, simple melodies and slow, sparse and slamming drums.

Political Hip Hop.Description: Developed in the 1980s; features explicitly political lyrics and themes.

Pop Rap.Description: Fuses Hip Hop's rapping and production traits with Pop elements such as melodious vocals and light, catchy tunes.

Ratchet Music.Description: Club-oriented Hip Hop pioneered by Mustard defined by a repeated synth melody and a sparse drum pattern often accompanied by a 'hey' chant.

Snap.Description: Prominent 808 bass and finger snaps, with lyrics primarily focused on nightclub topics (such as sex, drugs, and alcohol).

Southern Hip Hop.Description: Hip Hop from artists based in the Southern region of the United States.

Trap.Description: Originated in Atlanta in the early 2000s; distinctive fast hi-hat sound and heavy bass at moderate tempos.

Detroit Trap.Description: Emerging in Michigan during the 2010s and incorporating upbeat 808 percussion derived from Trap music and dynamic, off-beat flows from rappers.

Drill.Description: Originated in Chicago in the early 2010s, broadly characterized by complex, energetic rhythms, coupled with street-conscious and often violent rapping.

New Jazz.Description: Colorful, repetitive synths and synthetic instruments, playful vocal chops, and wonky bass selections set to bouncy Trap drums.

No Melody.Description: Usage of minimalistic, repetitive midtempo drum patterns, and simple, prominent 808s.

Plugg.Description: Use of sparse and minimalistic drum and hi-hat patterns, subby 808s and heavy low end, piano samples, airy pads, and icy synths.

Rage.Description: Dense, buzzing synth work with repetitive chord progressions and melodic synth leads.

Rare Phonk.Description: Primarily features eclectic sampling and lush, jazzy beats, usually set to Trap rhythms with prominent influences of Memphis Rap.

Regalia.Description: Lush, sweeping string arrangements, dreamy piano passages, and other orchestral instrumentation set to cinematic Trap percussion.

Sigilkore.Description: Dark and hyperactive production, featuring rapping laced with layers of effects.

Trap latino.Description: Distinguished by its Reggaet√≥n and Latin Rap roots, with smooth and moody production inspired by Alternative R&B and Contemporary R&B.

Trap Metal.Description: Features loud, distorted 808s and basslines, as well as aggressive vocals that are usually yelled or screamed.

Trap Soul.Description: Mixes passionate vocals derived from Contemporary R&B with laid-back, nocturnal and atmospheric Trap production.

Tread.Description: High-tempo production, usually set around 160 to 190 BPM, icy synths, busy drum programming with distinctive 808 patterns, often implementing off-beat hi-hats in addition to trap's triplets and a fast style of lethargic rapping.

Turntablism.Description: Manipulating and re-appropriating vinyl records using a turntable and DJ mixer in a hip hop context, developing from production techniques in the studio and on the stage.

UK Hip Hop.Description: Scene of the United Kingdom, influenced by American rap.

West Coast Hip Hop.Description: Artists who originate from the West Coast region of the United States.
